On 2/15/06, Ian Pilcher <i.pilcher@...> wrote:
> In this context, "testable" means a class that a TestRunner won't barf
> on.
>
> I am writing an Ant selector:
>
> http://ant.apache.org/manual/CoreTypes/selectors.html
>
> It's purpose is to identify the classes which should be "run" by an Ant
> JUnit task:
>
> <target name="test-run" depends="test-build">
> <junit>
> <batchtest>
> <fileset dir="test/bin"><junitselector/></fileset>
> </batchtest>
> </junit>
> </target>
>
> This will allow me to write a a generic testing target, without
> constraining the names of my test classes.
>
> In order to do this properly, I need a precise definition of what makes
> a class "testable" (in the above sense). Here's the algorithm that I've
> come up with:
>
> 1. Is the class public?
> * Yes - go to step 2
> * No - NOT testable - DONE
>
> 2. Is the class an interface?
> * Yes - NOT testable - DONE
> * No - go to step 3
>
> 3. Does the class have a "suite method" --
> public static Test suite()?
> * Yes - TESTABLE - DONE
> * No - go to step 4
>
> 4. Is the class abstract?
> * Yes - NOT testable - DONE
> * No - go to step 5
>
> 5. Does the class implement junit.framework.Test?
> * Yes - go to step 6
> * No - NOT testable - DONE
>
> 6. Does the class have a public default constructor --
> public <init>()?
> * Yes - TESTABLE - DONE
> * No - go to step 7
>
> 7. Does the class have a public string constructor --
> public <init>(String)?
> * Yes - TESTABLE - DONE
> * No - NOT testable - DONE
>
> Thoughts?
>
> Thanks!
